title: The Story of King Shripäl and Mayanä-sundari
subtitle: Section G.4 from JAB Manual

storyContent.tagHTML: King Singhrath of Champä-nagar died when his son, Prince Shripäl, was just five. The king's ambitious brother, Ajitsen, seized the throne and plotted to eliminate the young prince. Shripäl's mother, Queen Kamal-prabhä, fled with him. Pursued by soldiers, she made a desperate choice: she entrusted her son to a colony of lepers to save his life.

Shripäl grew up among the lepers and eventually contracted the disease himself. Despite this, his noble qualities shone through, and he became their leader, known as Umar Ränä. One day, his travels brought him and his group to the city of Ujjayini.

In Ujjayini, King Prajäpäl tested his two daughters. The elder, Sursundari, credited the king for her happiness. The younger, Mayanä-sundari, stated with firm faith that everything she had was the result of her own karma. Enraged by what he perceived as disrespect, the king decided to teach her a lesson. He found the'ugliest man' in the city—the leprous Umar Ränä (Shripäl)—and forcibly married Mayanä to him.

Mayanä, deeply religious, accepted her fate and cared for her husband. They sought guidance from Ächärya Munichandra, who advised them to perform the Navpad Ärädhanä, also known as Äyambil Oli—a nine-day penance of meditation and fasting. They devoutly observed the penance for four and a half years.

<svg class="story-icon" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 20 20" fill="currentColor"><path d="M11.983 1.904a.75.75 0 00-1.292-.782l-5.5 9.5a.75.75 0 001.292.782l5.5-9.5z" /><path d="M11.983 1.904a.75.75 0 00-1.292-.782l-5.5 9.5a.75.75 0 001.292.782l5.5-9.5z" /><path d="M2 10a.75.75 0 01.75-.75h14.5a.75.75 0 010 1.5H2.75A.75.75 0 012 10zM4.096 15.096a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l5.5-5.5a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-5.5 5.5z" /><path d="M5.156 10.596a.75.75 0 010-1.06l5.5-5.5a.75.75 0 111.06 1.06l-5.5 5.5a.75.75 0 01-1.06 0z" /></svg>The result was miraculous. Shripäl's leprosy was completely cured, and he regained his handsome princely form. King Prajäpäl, seeing this, realized the truth in his daughter's words about the power of karma. Shripäl's true identity was revealed, and he was welcomed back into the palace.

Feeling he needed to build his own fame rather than rely on his father-in-law's, Shripäl set out on his own. He traveled far and wide, amassing a great army and wealth, all while maintaining his devotion to the Navpad. He eventually returned to his home kingdom of Champä-nagar and challenged his usurper uncle, Ajitsen. Shripäl won the battle, reclaimed his throne, and gracefully released his uncle, who then renounced the world. King Shripäl ruled his kingdom happily with Mayanä-sundari for the rest of his life.

events.title: Father's Death
events.description: After King Singhrath dies, his ambitious brother Ajitsen seizes the throne of Champä-nagar.

events.title: A Desperate Escape
events.description: To save her son from Ajitsen, Queen Kamal-prabhä flees and entrusts the five-year-old Prince Shripäl to a colony of lepers.

events.title: Life as a Leper
events.description: Shripäl grows up in the colony, contracts leprosy, and eventually becomes their leader, known as Umar Ränä.

events.title: A King's Question
events.description: King Prajäpäl tests his daughters. Mayanä-sundari attributes her good fortune to her own karma, not the king's favor.

events.title: A Cruel Punishment
events.description: Enraged, the king marries Mayanä-sundari to Umar Ränä (Shripäl), the'ugliest man' he can find, to teach her a lesson.

events.title: A Guru's Advice
events.description: The couple seeks help from Ächärya Munichandra, who advises them to perform the Navpad Ärädhanä (Äyambil Oli) penance.

events.title: A Miraculous Cure
events.description: After four and a half years of devout penance, Shripäl is completely cured of leprosy and regains his princely appearance.

events.title: A Father's Realization
events.description: King Prajäpäl sees the transformation and finally understands the power of karma, welcoming his daughter and son-in-law back to the palace.

events.title: Building an Army
events.description: Shripäl leaves to make his own name, travels widely, and amasses a large army and great wealth.

events.title: Reclaiming the Throne
events.description: He returns to Champä-nagar, defeats his uncle Ajitsen in battle, and becomes the rightful king.

charactersData.name: King Shripäl
charactersData.description: A prince who was forced into exile, contracted leprosy, and was known as Umar Ränä. Through penance and faith, he was cured, built his own fortune, and reclaimed his rightful kingdom of Champä-nagar.

charactersData.name: Mayanä-sundari
charactersData.description: A princess with unwavering faith in the theory of karma. Punished by her father for this belief, she was married to a leper (Shripäl) but, through her devotion, was instrumental in his miraculous cure.

charactersData.name: King Prajäpäl
charactersData.description: The King of Ujjayini and Mayanä-sundari's father. His anger at his daughter's belief in karma led him to punish her, but he later learned the truth of her words.

charactersData.name: Ajitsen
charactersData.description: Shripäl's ambitious and cruel uncle, who usurped the throne of Champä-nagar after his brother's death and tried to have Shripäl killed.

charactersData.name: Ächärya Munichandra
charactersData.description: The learned Jain guru who advised Shripäl and Mayanä-sundari to perform the Navpad Ärädhanä (Äyambil Oli) penance, which led to the cure.

charactersData.name: Kamal-prabhä
charactersData.description: Shripäl's mother, who saved him from his uncle by entrusting him to a leper colony.

quizData.question: What was Prince Shripäl's name when he was living as the leader of the leper colony?
Who was Shripäl's cruel uncle who seized his throne?
In what city did King Prajäpäl rule?
What was Mayanä-sundari's answer to her father's question about her good fortune?
quizData.answer: She said it was the result of her own meritorious (Punya) karma.

quizData.question: How did King Prajäpäl punish Mayanä-sundari for her answer?
quizData.answer: He married her to Shripäl, who he thought was an ugly leper named Umar Ränä.

quizData.question: What is the name of the nine-day penance that Ächärya Munichandra advised the couple to perform?
What does the Äyambil penance involve?
quizData.answer: Eating only one meal a day of very plain food without any spices, milk, sugar, salt, oil, butter, fruits, or vegetables.

quizData.question: What miraculous event occurred after Shripäl and Mayanä performed the penance?
quizData.answer: Shripäl was completely cured of his leprosy.

quizData.question: After he was cured, why did Shripäl decide to leave Ujjayini and travel on his own?
quizData.answer: He felt sad that he was only being identified by his relationship to his father-in-law and wanted to gain fame through his own efforts.

quizData.question: What was the name of Shripäl's original kingdom that he eventually reclaimed?
How did Sursundari answer her father's question?
quizData.answer: She replied that she gained everything by the king’s favor.

quizData.question: The Navpad are the nine pious entities. Name three of them.
quizData.answer: Arihant, Siddha, Ächärya, Upädhyäy, Sädhu, Jnän (knowledge), Darshan (faith), Chäritra (conduct), and Tap (penance).

quizData.question: For how long did the couple have to perform the penance?
quizData.answer: For four and a half years.

quizData.question: What did Ajitsen do after Shripäl captured him and took back the kingdom?
quizData.answer: He felt his days were over and decided to renounce the worldly life.

graphicsData.title: A Mother's Desperate Choice
graphicsData.description: Fleeing from soldiers, Queen Kamal-prabhä tearfully entrusts her young son, Prince Shripäl, to a group of lepers to save his life.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A queen giving her child to a group of poor, sick people while looking back fearfully.

graphicsData.title: A Test of Belief
graphicsData.description: When asked by her father the source of her happiness, Princess Mayanä-sundari respectfully answers that it comes from her own good karma, not the king.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A princess speaking calmly to an angry-looking king on his throne.

graphicsData.title: A Cruel Marriage
graphicsData.description: As punishment, the enraged King Prajäpäl forces his daughter Mayanä-sundari to marry Umar Ränä (Shripäl), the leader of the lepers.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A sad princess being married to a man covered in rags and sores.

graphicsData.title: The Power of Penance
graphicsData.description: Advised by a wise Ächärya, Mayanä and Shripäl devoutly perform the Äyambil Oli, a rigorous penance of fasting and meditation.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A couple sitting in deep meditation, with simple food before them.

graphicsData.title: A Miraculous Transformation
graphicsData.description: Through their devotion, Shripäl is miraculously cured of his leprosy, revealing his true, handsome princely form to the astonishment of all.
graphicsData.imageAlt: The same man, now handsome and well-dressed, standing with his wife, looking healthy and strong.

graphicsData.title: Reclaiming the Kingdom
graphicsData.description: After building his own army, King Shripäl returns to his home of Champä-nagar and defeats his usurper uncle, reclaiming his rightful throne.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A king on horseback leading a large army towards a castle.
